title: Never use the word ‚ÄúUser‚Äù in your code
excerpt: You‚Äôre six months into a project when you realize a tiny, simple assumption you made at the start was completely wrong. And now you need to fix the problem while keeping the existing system running‚Äîwith far more effort than it would‚Äôve taken if you‚Äôd just gotten it right in the first place. Today I‚Äôd like to tell you about one common mistake, a single word that will cause you endless trouble. I am speaking, of course, about ‚Äúusers‚Äù. There are two basic problems with this word: ‚ÄúUser‚Äù is almost never a good description of your requirements. ‚ÄúUser‚Äù encourages a fundamental security design flaw. The concept ‚Äúuser‚Äù is dangerously vague, and you will almost always be better off using more accurate terminology.
